title: Furniture Delivery and Returns Routing
content:
A furniture store delivers new orders to customers and picks up old furniture for recycling or resale.  
Trucks must deliver all new sofas, tables, and chairs first before collecting any returns—otherwise, they’ll run out of space!  
The warehouse and customer locations are at `<locs>`, delivery demands are `<demand_linehaul>`, and pickup demands (like old mattresses or broken furniture) are `<demand_backhaul>`.  
Each truck has a capacity of `<capacity>`.  
The goal is to plan routes so deliveries happen smoothly, pickups don’t clog the trucks, and drivers avoid unnecessary detours.

title: E-Commerce Reverse Logistics
content:
An online retailer ships packages to customers and collects returns (like clothes that didn’t fit or defective gadgets).  
Trucks must drop off all new orders before picking up returns—otherwise, they’d mix new and old items, causing chaos!  
The warehouse and 20 customer locations are at `<locs>`, with delivery demands `<demand_linehaul>` and return demands `<demand_backhaul>`.  
Trucks have a capacity of `<capacity>`.  
The challenge is to assign routes so deliveries are fast, returns are consolidated efficiently, and no truck gets overloaded.

title: School Meal Delivery and Waste Collection
content:
A catering company delivers fresh meals to schools and picks up food waste for composting.  
Trucks *must* deliver meals first (kids can’t wait!) before collecting leftovers or trash.  
The kitchen depot and school locations are at `<locs>`, meal delivery demands are `<demand_linehaul>`, and waste pickup demands are `<demand_backhaul>`.  
Each truck holds up to `<capacity>`.  
Routes need to ensure meals arrive on time, waste is collected without delays, and trucks don’t exceed capacity (no spilled milk!).

title: Library Book Mobile Service
content:
A mobile library delivers reserved books to community centers and picks up overdue books for return.  
The van must distribute all new books first—otherwise, returned books might take up space needed for reservations!  
The library and 15 stop locations are at `<locs>`, with delivery demands `<demand_linehaul>` and return demands `<demand_backhaul>`.  
The van’s capacity is `<capacity>`.  
The goal is to plan a route that serves all stops efficiently, avoids backtracking, and keeps the van from overflowing with books.

title: Farm Produce and Empty Crate Collection
content:
A farm delivers fresh vegetables to markets and collects empty crates for reuse.  
Trucks must offload all produce first—if they pick up crates too early, there’s no room for deliveries!  
The farm and market locations are at `<locs>`, delivery demands are `<demand_linehaul>`, and crate pickup demands are `<demand_backhaul>`.  
Each truck’s capacity is `<capacity>`.  
The challenge is to optimize routes so veggies stay fresh, crates are reused efficiently, and trucks don’t waste fuel circling back.

title: Laundry Service for Hotels and Restaurants
content:
I run a commercial laundry service that picks up dirty linens from hotels and restaurants, cleans them, and delivers fresh ones.  
Each truck starts at the laundry facility with clean tablecloths, napkins, and bedsheets. It must deliver these to customers first before collecting their dirty laundry.  
If routes aren’t planned well, trucks might backtrack or run out of space for dirty linens because they didn’t drop off enough clean ones first.  
The locations of the laundry facility and all the hotels/restaurants is `<locs>`, the delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the pickup demand is `<demand_backhaul>`.  
The truck has a capacity of `<capacity>`.  
I need to optimize routes so that deliveries happen efficiently, pickups are completed without wasted trips, and no truck is overloaded.

title: Construction Material Delivery and Debris Removal
content:
I manage a construction supply company that delivers materials (like lumber, cement, and tools) to job sites and collects waste (like scrap metal and broken pallets) for recycling.  
Trucks must drop off all new supplies before loading any debris—otherwise, they might not have room for deliveries.  
Some sites need urgent materials, while others have piles of waste waiting to be hauled away.  
The locations of the warehouse and all the construction sites is `<locs>`, the delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the pickup demand is `<demand_backhaul>`.

I need a routing plan that ensures timely deliveries, efficient debris collection, and minimal fuel waste—all while keeping trucks from exceeding weight limits.

content:
I coordinate deliveries for a retail chain where trucks restock shelves with new products and pick up expired or unsold items for returns.

content:
I work for a pharmacy chain that delivers prescription medications to patients' homes and also collects expired or unused drugs for safe disposal.

content:

content: I run a meal kit subscription service where we deliver fresh ingredients to customers’ doorsteps. content:

content:

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing and Sample Collection
content:
A healthcare provider operates mobile testing vans that visit neighborhoods to conduct COVID-19 tests. After testing, the same vans must collect completed test samples and transport them to a lab for processing.  
The challenge? Tests must be administered before samples can be picked up—you can’t mix the two tasks. If routes aren’t optimized, vans might backtrack unnecessarily, delay lab results, or miss high-priority areas.  
The locations of the lab (starting point) and all testing sites is `<locs>`, the testing demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the sample collection demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Each van has capacity `<capacity>`.  
I need a route plan that ensures tests are done efficiently while samples reach the lab quickly, minimizing travel time and keeping communities safe.

title: Snack Vending Machine Restocking and Cash Collection
content:
I manage a fleet of vans that restock snacks in office vending machines and collect cash from the machines’ coin boxes.

content:

content:
A coastal business rents umbrellas to tourists in the morning and collects them at sunset. Deliveries (setting up umbrellas) must happen before pickups (taking them down).

title: Mobile Blood Donation and Sample Transport
content: I coordinate a mobile blood donation service where vans travel to offices, schools, and community centers to collect blood donations. The challenge is that blood samples are time-sensitive—they must reach labs quickly—but the vans can’t mix pickups and drop-offs haphazardly. I need to plan routes so donations are collected efficiently, samples reach labs on time, and no van exceeds its capacity or wastes fuel.

title: Hazardous Waste Disposal and Clean Supply Delivery
content: A chemical company delivers fresh cleaning supplies to factories while also collecting hazardous waste for safe disposal. Trucks must deliver clean supplies first before handling toxic pickups to avoid contamination. If routes aren’t optimized, drivers might backtrack unnecessarily or violate safety protocols. title: Bookstore Inventory Rotation and Unsold Returns
content: A bookstore chain sends trucks to restock branches with new books while collecting unsold inventory to return to publishers. Deliveries must happen before pickups to avoid mixing fresh and returned stock. Some stores are in busy malls with tight delivery windows, making route planning tricky. The locations of the warehouse and stores are `<locs>`. The delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the return demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Each truck has a capacity of `<capacity>`. I need routes that ensure all stores get their new books on schedule, returns are collected efficiently, and trucks don’t waste time circling the city.

title: Aquaponics Farm Produce Delivery and Waste Collection
content: An urban aquaponics farm delivers fresh fish and vegetables to restaurants while picking up food scraps for compost. Trucks must drop off perishable goods first before loading smelly compost to avoid spoilage. Poor routing could mean late deliveries or half-empty trucks driving extra miles. The locations of the farm, restaurants, and compost sites are `<locs>`. The delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the compost collection demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Each truck has a refrigerated capacity of `<capacity>`. I need a plan that keeps deliveries fresh, compost pickups efficient, and fuel costs low.

title: Mobile Vet Clinic and Shelter Animal Transfers
content: A mobile veterinary clinic visits neighborhoods to provide pet checkups while also transporting rescue animals between shelters. The van must finish all appointments before loading animals for transfer to avoid stress. Shelters have limited space, so timing is critical. The locations of the clinic, appointment sites, and shelters are `<locs>`. The service demand (appointments) is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the animal transfer demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. The van has a capacity of `<capacity>` cages. I need routes that maximize daily appointments, ensure safe animal transfers, and minimize driving time between stops.

title: Mobile Pet Grooming Service
content: A pet grooming company operates a fleet of vans that provide at-home grooming services. Each van starts the day loaded with clean towels, shampoos, and tools. After grooming pets at customers' homes, the vans collect dirty towels and used supplies to bring back for cleaning. The challenge is to schedule routes so that all appointments are met on time, and dirty items are collected efficiently without overloading the vans. The locations of the grooming depot and all customers is `<locs>`, the service demand (time per appointment) is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the dirty supply load is `<demand_backhaul>`. Each van has capacity `<capacity>`. The goal is to minimize travel time while ensuring no van exceeds its capacity for clean/dirty items.

title: Campus Mail and Package Redistribution
content: A university’s mail center delivers packages to departments and picks up outgoing mail from campus buildings. Delivery trucks start with a full load of incoming parcels and must drop them off before collecting outgoing mail. Some buildings receive heavy shipments (e.g., labs), while others generate large volumes of outgoing mail (e.g., admin offices). The locations of the mail center and all campus stops is `<locs>`, the delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the pickup demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Trucks have capacity `<capacity>`. The goal is to avoid backtracking, ensure timely deliveries, and fit all pickups within truck limits.

title: Home Appliance Installation and Haul-Away
content: A retailer offers appliance installation (e.g., refrigerators, washers) and removes old units for recycling. Trucks leave the warehouse with new appliances, install them at homes, then load the old appliances before returning. The twist: installs must happen before haul-aways, and old appliances often take more space than new ones. The locations of the warehouse and all customer homes is `<locs>`, the delivery demand (new units) is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the pickup demand (old units) is `<demand_backhaul>`. Trucks have capacity `<capacity>`. The challenge is to avoid routes where trucks fill up on old appliances too early, leaving no room for more.

title: Farmers’ Cooperative Seed and Harvest Routing
content: A farming co-op distributes seeds and fertilizers to member farms in spring, then collects harvested crops in fall. Delivery trucks must distribute inputs first before circling back to pick up produce. Some farms are seed-heavy (large fields), while others generate more harvest (orchards). The locations of the co-op hub and all farms is `<locs>`, the seed/fertilizer demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the crop pickup demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Trucks have capacity `<capacity>`. The goal is to balance routes so trucks don’t run out of space for crops after delivering seeds.

title: Mobile Phone Repair and Replacement Service
content: A tech company offers doorstep phone repairs. Vans start at a service center with replacement parts, fix phones at customers’ locations, and collect broken parts for refurbishment. Deliveries (new parts) must happen before pickups (old parts), and some repairs require multiple components. The locations of the service center and all customers is `<locs>`, the part delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the broken part collection is `<demand_backhaul>`. Vans have capacity `<capacity>`. The challenge is to group nearby jobs while ensuring vans don’t overflow with defective parts before finishing repairs.

title: Mobile Library and Book Donation Service
content:
Our county library runs a mobile service that delivers books to schools, nursing homes, and remote communities. After dropping off requested books, the van also collects donated books from these locations to replenish the library’s stock.  
The challenge? The van must deliver all books before accepting donations to avoid mixing new and old inventory.  
The locations of the library hub and all stops is `<locs>`, the delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the donation collection demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. The van has capacity `<capacity>`.  
I need to plan routes so no stop is missed, donations don’t overcrowd the van, and fuel costs stay low—all while keeping book lovers happy!

title: Office Coffee Service and Used Pod Recycling
content:
A coffee supplier delivers fresh coffee pods to offices and picks up used pods for recycling. Trucks must drop off new supplies first because empty pods take up space and can’t mix with deliveries.  
Some offices order weekly, while others have bins overflowing with used pods waiting for pickup.  
The locations of the supplier and all offices is `<locs>`, the pod delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the recycling collection demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Trucks have capacity `<capacity>`.  
I need routes that ensure no office runs out of coffee, all recyclables are collected, and trucks don’t waste time backtracking.

content:
A city program delivers fresh compost to community gardens and urban farms, then collects plant scraps to turn into next month’s compost.  
Trucks must unload compost first—otherwise, scraps would dirty the cargo area and delay deliveries.  
The locations of the compost center and all gardens is `<locs>`, the compost delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the scrap collection demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Each truck holds `<capacity>`.  
The goal? Keep gardens thriving, avoid spoiled loads, and minimize diesel emissions across the city.

content:
A firewood company supplies cabins and campsites in the mountains. After dropping off firewood, trucks collect ash from fire pits to dispose of safely.  
Deliveries come first—ash is messy and can’t share space with clean firewood!  
The locations of the depot and all customer sites is `<locs>`, the firewood demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the ash collection demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Trucks fit `<capacity>`.  
I need routes that ensure cozy campfires, clean sites, and no wasted trips on winding mountain roads.

content:
A fleet of mobile car wash vans services parking lots at offices and apartments. They carry clean water for washing, then vacuum up dirty water for recycling.  
Wash water must be used first—once tanks are full of dirty water, no more cars can be cleaned!  
The locations of the water station and all lots is `<locs>`, the clean water demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the wastewater collection demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Vans hold `<capacity>`.  
The challenge? Keep cars shiny, avoid overflow spills, and optimize routes so no van runs dry mid-shift.

content:
I run a plant nursery that delivers fresh flowers and potted plants to homes and businesses. After deliveries, we also pick up empty pots and trays from customers who want to recycle them.

The locations of our nursery and all customers is `<locs>`, the delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and the empty pot collection demand is `<demand_backhaul>`.

I need a route plan that ensures timely deliveries, efficient pickups, and minimal wasted trips—so we don’t drive halfway across town just to grab one empty pot.

content:
My bakery delivers fresh bread to cafes and grocery stores every morning. On the same trip, we collect yesterday’s unsold bread (which we donate or compost).

content: A farming co-op delivers seeds and tools to members in spring, then picks up harvested crops in fall—all with the same trucks. content: Our local health department runs a mobile vaccination van that visits schools, nursing homes, and community centers to administer vaccines. content: Our eco-friendly car wash van drives to offices and neighborhoods, cleaning vehicles on-site. After washing, it pumps dirty water into tanks to recycle at our facility. The catch? title: Farmers’ Cooperative Seed and Harvest Routing
content: Our farming co-op delivers seeds and supplies to members in spring, then picks up harvested crops in fall—all using the same trucks. content: We supply coffee machines and pods to offices, swapping out empty pods for recycling. Trucks must restock pods first—no one wants recycled grounds spilling near fresh coffee! The locations of our roastery and all offices is `<locs>`, the pod deliveries are `<demand_linehaul>`, and the used pods to collect are `<demand_backhaul>`. Each truck fits `<capacity>` pods. title: Mobile Laundromat Service for Apartment Complexes
content:
A laundry company provides weekly pickup and drop-off services for apartment residents. Their vans first deliver clean, folded clothes to customers and then collect bags of dirty laundry on the same trip.  
The challenge is that they can’t mix deliveries and pickups—clean clothes must be dropped off before dirty laundry is collected. If routes aren’t optimized, drivers waste time circling back to neighborhoods or run out of space for dirty laundry.  
The locations of the laundry facility and all apartment complexes is <locs>, the clean laundry demand is <demand_linehaul>, and the dirty laundry collection is <demand_backhaul>.  
The van has capacity <capacity>.  
I need to plan routes that ensure timely deliveries while efficiently collecting laundry, minimizing mileage, and keeping loads balanced.

content:
A swimming pool service company delivers fresh chemicals (chlorine, pH balancers) to hotels and private homes while collecting empty plastic containers for recycling.  
Trucks must deliver full containers first before picking up empties—you can’t swap them at the same time due to safety regulations. Poor routing leads to trucks doubling back or missing recycling deadlines.  
The locations of the depot and all service points is <locs>, chemical delivery demand is <demand_linehaul>, and empty container pickup is <demand_backhaul>.  
The truck has capacity <capacity>.  
The goal is to schedule routes that ensure pools stay properly maintained while efficiently handling container returns, avoiding hazardous material handling violations.

title: College Dorm Move-In/Move-Out Assistance
content:
A university hires a moving service to help students during semester transitions. Trucks deliver rented furniture (mini-fridges, microwaves) to dorm rooms at the start of term, then collect the same items at semester’s end.  
Deliveries must be completed before any pickups begin—you can’t have trucks half-full of outgoing fridges while trying to deliver new ones.  
The locations of the storage warehouse and all dorm buildings is <locs>, furniture delivery needs are <demand_linehaul>, and collection quantities are <demand_backhaul>.  
Each truck holds <capacity> items.  
We need routes that minimize disruption during busy move-in/out days while ensuring no student waits excessively for their furniture or return pickup.

title: Film Set Equipment Logistics
content:
A movie production company transports cameras, lighting gear, and props to shooting locations daily, then retrieves equipment after filming wraps.  
Critical rule: All morning deliveries must finish before afternoon pickups (you can’t swap a used spotlight for a new one at the same stop). Poor planning causes expensive equipment shortages on set.  
The locations of the studio lot and all shooting sites is <locs>, equipment delivery needs are <demand_linehaul>, and retrieval lists are <demand_backhaul>.  
Each truck carries <capacity> kg of gear.  
The solution must coordinate routes so equipment arrives precisely when needed for shoots and returns efficiently without requiring extra vehicles.

title: Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) Box Rotation
content:
A farm delivers weekly CSA vegetable boxes to neighborhood pickup points, then collects last week’s empty wooden crates for reuse.  
Trucks must distribute fresh produce first—empty crate collection only happens after all deliveries are complete to prevent mixing. Bad routing leads to spoiled produce or missing crates.  
The locations of the farm and all pickup hubs is <locs>, vegetable box demand is <demand_linehaul>, and empty crate returns are <demand_backhaul>.  
Each truck fits <capacity> crates.  
We need routes that ensure subscribers get fresh veggies before noon while recovering all crates before the next packing day, keeping fuel costs low for the small farm.

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing and Sample Collection
content:
Our city runs mobile testing vans that visit neighborhoods to conduct COVID-19 tests. After testing, the same vans must collect samples and transport them to the lab for processing.  
The challenge? Vans can’t mix testing and sample collection—they must finish all tests before loading any biohazard containers. If routes aren’t optimized, we risk delays in getting results or vans doubling back unnecessarily.  
The locations of the lab (starting point) and 20 testing sites is <locs>. Testing demand (swabs/PPE to deliver) is <demand_linehaul>, while sample collection demand is <demand_backhaul>. Each van has capacity <capacity>.  
We need routes that maximize daily tests while ensuring timely lab delivery, all while keeping biohazard separation protocols.

title: Firewood Delivery and Ash Cleanup Service
content:
I operate a firewood subscription service for rural homes. Trucks deliver seasoned wood before winter, then return in spring to collect ash bins for safe disposal.  
Here’s the twist: Trucks can’t carry ash and firewood simultaneously—deliveries must finish before ash pickups begin. Poor routing means driving past homes multiple times or leaving customers waiting for ash removal.  
The locations of our depot and 15 farmhouses is <locs>. Firewood bundles to deliver total <demand_linehaul>, while ash bins to collect total <demand_backhaul>. Each truck holds <capacity>.  
We need routes that sync with seasonal timing while minimizing muddy backroad travel.

content:
Our animal welfare organization runs mobile vet clinics that visit underserved areas. After providing care, we transport shelter-bound animals back to our facility.  
The catch? We can’t mix medical deliveries (vaccines/supplies) with live animal pickups—safety requires completing all clinics first. Inefficient routes stress animals and waste limited refrigerated storage.  
The locations of our HQ and 12 community stops is <locs>. Medical supply demand is <demand_linehaul>, while animal transfer slots needed is <demand_backhaul>. Each van has <capacity>.  
Routes must prioritize vaccine cold chain integrity while minimizing animal transport time.

The locations of our co-op hub and 18 farms is <locs>. Spring input demand is <demand_linehaul>, fall harvest volume is <demand_backhaul>. Each truck holds <capacity>.  
We need seasonal route plans that account for varying farm road conditions and perishability.

content:

Each truck starts at the warehouse loaded with new phones, makes deliveries, then picks up trade-ins—but only after all deliveries are done (to avoid mixing new and used inventory). The locations of the warehouse and customer stops is `<locs>`, new phone demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and trade-in demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Trucks have capacity `<capacity>`. If routes aren’t optimized, drivers waste time circling neighborhoods or run out of space for trade-ins. I need a plan that maximizes daily trade-ins while minimizing miles driven.

title: Urban Composting Collection
content: Our city’s composting program delivers empty compost bins to households weekly, then collects them once they’re filled with food scraps. Trucks must drop off clean bins first before picking up full ones (to avoid cross-contamination). The locations of the composting facility and households is `<locs>`, empty bin delivery demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and full bin demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Each truck holds `<capacity>` bins. Bad routing means some neighborhoods get missed, or trucks return half-empty. I need a system that ensures all bins are swapped efficiently while reducing fuel use.

title: Rental Uniform Service for Factories
content: Factories rent work uniforms from us—we deliver clean uniforms and pick up dirty ones for laundering. Each truck must drop off clean gear before collecting soiled items (to keep them separate). The locations of the laundry depot and factories is `<locs>`, clean uniform demand is `<demand_linehaul>`, and dirty uniform demand is `<demand_backhaul>`. Trucks have capacity `<capacity>`. If routes aren’t planned well, drivers waste time doubling back or factories run short on uniforms. I need a routing plan that keeps all factories stocked and our laundry trucks full on return trips.
